H0.text: Which radioactive substance sometimes occurs naturally in spring water. Uranium

H1.text: Which radioactive substance sometimes occurs naturally in spring water. Radium

H2.text: Which radioactive substance sometimes occurs naturally in spring water. Thorium

H3.text: Which radioactive substance sometimes occurs naturally in spring water. Radon

A4.text: The towns of Boulder, Montana; Misasa; Bad Kreuznach, Germany; and the country of Japan have radium-rich springs that emit radon.

A5.text: High concentrations of radon can be found in some spring waters and hot springs.

A6.text: Radium is part of the decay chains of natural thorium and uranium isotopes; since thorium and uranium have very long half-lives, these daughters are continually being regenerated by their decay.

A7.text: The immediate decay product of radium is radon gas, which is responsible for much of the danger of environmental radium.
